channel.title: Journal on Tobyblog
channel.description: Recent content in Journal on Tobyblog

item.title: Real Life Pokemon on my Walk
item.description: Evolved my Ekans into a Daehreppoc. üêç Not bad, huh? But this was my luckiest catch of the day. CORONAVIRUS, I CHOOSE YOU!

item.title: Lunchtime Walks on Quarantine
item.description: Things have become very busy for me over the last couple of weeks. I’ve been given primary streaming and video responsibilities for our church during the lockdown, all the while ramping up for a new gig at my job, and working on an interesting side project as well ‚Äî a product shoot for a friend at church who is opening up an Etsy store. (On a side note, I’ve never done anything like that and was honored that she even asked.

item.title: The CV Lockdown Blues. Missing California.
item.description: I suppose it can’t be helped; every year as March drags into April, as the days get hotter and the brief Texas spring looks more toward the summer, the early zeal of the Lenten discipline wears off, and the sacrifices once willingly undertaken become an annoyance and a burden. These things are only compounded by the enforced isolation and the looming prospect of an almost anti-climatic, if not mildly depressing, Pascha undertaken as it is this year without the usual joy of communal celebration.

item.title: Lunch Options
item.description: I was at the juice bar today getting an ‚ÄúImmune Booster‚Äù (beet, ginger, cayenne ‚Äî I could use it right now)‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶when I noticed this alternative It was a cup of donuts. They were selling donuts by the cup. At the juice bar. Today, I chose wisely.

item.title: Santa's Story Time at NorthPark Mall
Weird Science
Playing / Kitchen and Bar
St. Nicholas Orthodox Church, December 2019
Breckinridge Park 1219
Happy Birthday, Kass
item.description: Wishing the best of birthdays to my beloved and fellow blogger. If only it could be from Hawaii again this year. I promise to make some Mai Tais this weekend to commemorate it, and maybe post some of those pics.

item.title: Astrophil & Stella
Last Day in November
Arches National Park
Turning 31
item.description: About damn time.

item.title: ‚ÄòTis the Season of Big Trees
Forestwood Antiques
Christmas Time at the Mall
Date Night at Northpark
Old Tree Off Rowlett Creek
The Fight For Baby Tinslee
item.description: I got to tag along recently to an impromptu press conference called at Cook Children’s Medical Center in Ft. Worth by Texas Right to Life ‚Äî you can read about the unfortunate circumstances here. We were expecting Kassi to speak to the legal issues involved, but she wasn’t questioned at that time.

item.title: A Walk Around Northpark Mall
Fall in Plano
A Sunset Walk in November
Pho in the Rain
Slavoj Zizek on The Joker
item.description: He’s not a fan of the new Joker, though he greatly admires Nolan’s version. The truth is in your mask. The truth is in what you are doing. Interesting take. Paradoxically, a mask means I can be who I really am. His point, based in some psychological theory, is that our plain faces are the real masks; that in our normal lives we artificially conform ourselves because of social convention, expectations, etc; but that “our mask” allows us to break out of those restrictions, inviting the true self ‚Äì¬†the inner or even unconscious self ‚Äì to emerge.

item.title: Kassi Blogs the Plano Balloon Fest
item.description: Because I wanted to share her picture of me stuffing my face with a gigantic turkey leg. Also, ‘Murica.

item.title: Kassi Blogs the Little Elm Autumn Fest
item.description: She’s right, the Little Elm Autumn Fest was a blast. We went Friday on Oktoberfest night and the polka band was amazing, as were the food trucks and local craft beer. It was crowded, and we had to park a fair distance away, but we had a good time and were able to do what we went there to do. This is gonna be on our must-do list next year, but I think I’d like to get there earlier.

item.title: Hermione's Spiel
item.description: She went on: ‚ÄúI never believed the whole ‚ÄòI‚Äôm happy single‚Äô spiel. I was like, ‚ÄòThis is totally spiel.‚Äô It took me a long time, but I‚Äôm very happy [being single]. I call it being self-partnered.‚Äù The only story here is how much Emma Watson uses the Hollywood word spiel.

item.title: Happy Halloween, 2019
Nine Useless Jack O' Lantern Templates
item.description: Most of these were taken from the huge catalog of templates over at Stoneykins.com, the vast majority of which are pretty cool and definitely not useless.

item.title: Pumpkin Hollow 2019
A Day in October
Downtown Fever on Stage at the Plano Balloon Festival
Seeing Zion National Park
Love Is a Many Splendored Thing
item.description: One of my earliest memories is asking my mom to borrow an old Hallmark music box that played this song. It was important to me, though I couldn’t explain why. I’d listen to it over and over again, long past the point of annoyance to everyone. Sometimes at night, when I was scared, I’d listen to it to help me sleep. It has a sad, but sweet melody. At about 2:00 it has the proper timing, then very quickly starts to unwind.

item.title: Our Trip to the Grand Canyon
Faces
item.description:
Time does take its toll on the body.

What do you see when you look into a funhouse mirror? Another “you” staring out at you beneath the surface of the glass? Maybe you are really just one of a whole army of such “you"s, none knowing for sure what side of the glass he falls on. Maybe the “you” you are now is just another picture frozen in time; something separate and distinct from all your past and future selves. Always dying, always being born; every thought and action carving its mark forever into the lines of your face and body.

Now imagine an app on your phone that would let you peer into that funhouse ‚Äî¬†would let you see those possibilities, those infinite “you"s that could have been. That will be?

Well, particularly those possibilities that involve you growing a beard, dying your hair, looking like a douchebag, or getting really old.

item.title: Crow at the Grand Canyon
item.description: Who’s ready for fall? You can count me in, though I’m not sure “ready” is the best word for it. Summer seemed to pass by so fast this year. Barely had time to really enjoy it, it seems, before it’s practically gone. They say this happens as you get older, but I suspect in my case it has more to do with a dearth of time spent outside this year, soaking up sun and heat.

item.title: Working From Malls
item.description: I love working from shopping malls. I was just telling Kassi the other day that they offer several advantages that suit me and my work style well. Doors open early. Easy access to restrooms. Most have at least some access to power; and free wifi, though I always tether. The ambient noise is generally at an appropriate level, though my current environment has somewhat more than the usual. More than anything I appreciate the large, wide open spaces and natural light that filters in through the ceiling glass.

item.title: Red Rock State Park
A History of the Puffy Toilet Seat
item.description: I always considered those things the grossest of the gross. But did get me thinking about alternative “comfortable” materials. A gel toilet seat? Cushion of air? Water? Yeah, like a water bed ‚Äî but instead it’s a toilet seat. And if you don’t already follow the bro-science blog of Dollar Shave Club, you should. Way better than The Onion these days.

item.title: The Importance of Good Shoes
item.description: Never forget your good business shoes on a business trip. #roadwarrior #protip

item.title: Awkward Elevator Moments
item.description: That feeling when you neglect to hold the elevator for someone, but somehow they manage to press the button at the very last moment, and they know what the hell you just did, and you have to ride up several floors together in awkward silence.

item.title: Our Dog Frank
RIP Frank Dog, 2013 ‚Äì 2019
item.description: I‚Äôm sorry, Frank. Despite driving us crazy sometimes, you were ever a good friend and protector. I know it wasn‚Äôt you‚Äôre fault. I hope somehow you understood.

item.title: My Worst Vacation Injuries
item.description: We’ve visited a few spots with some potential for accidents, but so far my worst vacation injuries have been banging my head on the roof of the car unloading luggage (last year; my neck was sore for days), and scraping up my arm pretty bad after tripping over luggage in the dark (last night). It seems I have a problem with luggage.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 09.01
item.description: Arrived in beautiful Telluride, Colorado, and yes, this is my first update since day #2 of vacation. So much for my Travel Log. Between lack of cell signal and surrendering my phone to the kid, and straight up being too busy and/or exhausted, I haven‚Äôt had much opportunity for posting. We‚Äôve been busy! Back to the Grand Canyon this year, and this time we got to spend a night in the park, with a chance to do some dawn/dusk shots of the canyon itself.

item.title: What‚Äôs Your Smell?
item.description: I wonder what coffee, grass, and new computer would smell like?

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 02.02
item.description: Finally made it to Red Rock State Park, and made a couple of new discoveries along the way. Our route took us through what turned out be the incredibly beautiful Coconino National Forest, a place we have vowed to return. If Tolkien‚Äôs Elves were a real thing, they might just choose to live in a place like that. Verdant green forests around the bases of giant granite mountains, interspersed all along the way with little villages and expensive looking cabin retreats, with lights hanging from the trees across bridges that span crystal clear mountain streams.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 02.01
item.description: On the road from Albuquerque to Flagstaff, near which we turn south to Red Rock State Park in Arizona. The kids are keen to get in a hike today, the first ‚Äúreal‚Äù day of our vacation, as far as I‚Äôm concerned. It‚Äôs been fun watching the younger two get excited over taking pictures from the car with the little Instax Mini. That was Kassi‚Äôs great idea. We bought Anthony around 150 exposures and his eyes got wide when I told him I wanted him to use every single one by the end of the trip.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 01.02
item.description: Picture of me in the Llano Estacado, Texas‚Äôs ‚Äúwine country‚Äù. On the road for quite a while and still not out of the state. Holding up well. Fear the little one may be coming down with a cold. Hope he‚Äôs better after some rest. Changed restaurant plans and will revisit our old favorite in Albuquerque for the third year in a row. The food there has always been great, though the service is consistently slow.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 01.01
item.description: We‚Äôre well in to the big family road trip of 2019, and the obligatory Texas pit stop at Bucc-ees has been checked off the list. Would have sent you guys a pic from the storied Bucc-ees bathrooms, but I was too excited about these new hot n‚Äô spicy Beaver Nuggets! You can hear all about my first experience with those glorified Corn Pops in this review I did last year with my good buddy Brian.

item.title: See You in Arizona
item.description: It’s summer vacation time again, and I’m as excited as if I were returning to Hogwarts after a summer at the Dursley’s ‚Äî¬†a completely made up expression that I thought of just now purely as an excuse to post the picture below, of which I happen to be fond. Back when I had hair I might have been able to pass off a kind of Harry Potter-esque look. Now it’s more like Filch.

item.title: Pasadena Tour
Taking Kassi to the Channel Islands
Work Day With My Son
item.description: Having an excellent and productive work day with the boy üë¶

item.title: Visiting Sequoia National Park
Flight to LA With Kassi
The Dad Wagon is in Vacation Mode
item.description: Must be time for a road trip, because I find myself wondering what the wagon would look like with wood paneling. üöô‚õ∞üèú

item.title: Halloween Hits The Shelves
item.description: Well, well. Look who‚Äôs back. I‚Äôve heard rumors that the Lemax stuff is already on sale at Michaels, too.

item.title: Farewell Pasadena
COPS: Flushing Drugs Could Create ‚ÄúMeth-Gators‚Äù
item.description: The Alabama Meth-Gators is my new favorite college football team.

item.title: A Fire Sign
item.description: The name of this sculpture is Entwine, I think a reference to The Lord of the Rings. It‚Äôs supposed to be a tree, or plant, to symbolize Wylie‚Äôs connection to its roots. I always thought of it as a campfire, and I think that imagery fits much better for a library.

item.title: Independence Day 2019
Bolin Park
Bits and Bobs
item.description: I made a promise to myself that I would never waste time on this blog apologizing for sporadic posting. So instead of doing that, I think I’ll do that other thing where I throw a few pictures at you and catch you up on recent developments.

item.title: Show Some Love To My Spouseblog
item.description: If you haven’t been following Kassi over on her personal blog, by all means go there and check it out. She’s been killing it lately, posting about all the family stuff I’m supposed to be getting to over on this site, but have been too lame to do. I swear she can fire off 3 or 4 posts by the time I’m done editing the same number of photos. Practice, I guess?

item.title: Known Walkers
item.description: One wonders how one gets to be a known walker. Do you introduce yourself? Do you have to register at the office? Are there name tags? In any event, I would love to get my hands on that (presumably massive) unknown mall walker dossier down at the precinct. Must be how they break in the rookie detectives.

item.title: Some Classic 80s For Sale
item.description: These were like 10 cents a piece before Ready Player One came out. #classic80s

item.title: Independence Day 2019
item.description: There‚Äôs no denying we live in troubled times in this country. Shared celebrations are a respite from the hate that seems set to smother our culture. They also serve as milestones, reminding us of the passage of time and providing a useful historical perspective on our own lives and the times we share with each other. For our part, we plan to celebrate like we haven‚Äôt in a while, venturing down to the mall later for the big party, then fireworks later tonight. Before that I‚Äôll be grilling pizzas in the backyard, and I hope to get a lot of today on camera.

item.title: The Bunny Run
Odds and Ends
item.description: Let’s just say today feels more like Kelsey Grammer than Jason Momoa.

item.title: Facebucks Was My Idea
item.description: Man, Zuckerberg really dropped the ball with the name for his new crypto-money. Libra? Really? When FACEBUCKS is staring you right in the… face? Hell, even ZuckBucks would have been better than that.

item.title: Things to See on a Lunchtime Walk
Old Photos and Re-Edits
Yo Mama
item.description: Enjoying hearing the lady at Central Market giving out samples of Yo Mama pasta sauce yelling ‚ÄúYo Mama‚Äù at people as they pass by.

item.title: Backdoor Man
item.description: Know your escape routes. #totalsituationalawareness

item.title: Kodachrome
item.description: Been reading a bit about Kodachrome film processing since I saw this picture on a photo forum. Those vivid, deep colors really get to me. I‚Äôm trying to understand the color principles well enough to reproduce something like that in my own photo processing.

item.title: From A Morning Hike At RCP
The Obligatory Moon Shots with the Nikon P1000
Firewheels at Arbor Hills
Gor
item.description: Earlier today I had the honor of being driven around by Gor, who I think is some sort of barbarian king in his main job.

item.title: Error in Transmission
item.description: Well, the Dad Wagon is officially in the shop, up on blocks, awaiting a complete transmission replacement, which ought to take a few weeks. What went wrong I have no idea. Until then my skies will be the color of my grey sedan loner, and I’ll be singing the blues üöô till I’m cruising the highways once again in my Marakesh brown leather seats.

item.title: Hogs Head Cheese: A Disappearing Delicacy
item.description: I can’t claim that I was one who helped to postpone the extinction. Somebody told me once as a kid that it contained pig’s brains, so I never ate it. It pretty much looked like jello’d meat, too, which didn’t add to the appeal. I’d try it today, though, if I still lived there, and probably would like it. Vinegar and pork is not a bad combo.

item.title: My New Pet Peeve
item.description: My new pet peeve ‚Äî automatic sliding doors that stop halfway through the slide, causing you to ram your chest and face into them like a jackass and almost break the door down besides

item.title: Do Ants Like Coffee?
item.description: üêú‚ù§Ô∏è‚òïÔ∏è Ants are my favorite insect. That they have actually been observed to plant coffee seeds, live in and among the plants they grow, and actually harvest the beans floors me with wonder for these remarkable creatures that are so different from us, yet so much resemble us in our social behaviors. This is real agriculture; and we already know they practice ranching and husbandry behaviors, with aphids for example ‚Äî “milking” them of the dew produced by their bodies.

item.title: Maga Hat
item.description: I live in Dallas and tonight was the first time I have ever seen anyone wearing a #MAGA hat out in public. Some old guy at Lowes. Just thought I should document that for posterity. And no, he did not appear to be buying any tiki torches, nor was his heart very obviously consumed with hatred for brown people, so as to make me hate him. Just an old man.

item.title: Evening Walk, March 2019
Deutschland
item.description: Just caught the soft jazz, muzak version of Deutschland Uber Alles over the speakers at Hobby Lobby just now, and had the feeling that I‚Äôd crossed into that alternate timeline where the Germans won WWII.

item.title: Bee on a Firewheel
The Holdouts of Collin Creek
item.description: There are only a handful of stores left standing now at Collin Creek Mall in Plano. It‚Äôll all be torn down soon. I‚Äôve worked many mornings from the food court there, just me and the old folks who walk the mall and meet up for coffee. The mall is being razed to build a new billion dollar open air, multi-use development that will host stores, apartments, green space, and even a “lagoon” of all things.

item.title: Muskrat Love
item.description: Just walked up on two skunks fornicating. üíàüê±‚ù§Ô∏è

item.title: Alyssa Stank
item.description: In trying to recall the name of my new favorite artist after the Cottonwood show, I somehow misremembered her name as ‚ÄúAlyssa Stank‚Äù, which I actually googled. Alyssa Stank. That could be a name. Right?

item.title: Richardson's Cottonwood Art Festival
item.description:
Somewhere around the beginning of May (and again in the fall) the city of Richardson, Texas invites artists from across the country to gather in Cottonwood Park for a big market day celebration of beauty and imagination. The Cottonwood Art Festival features some brilliant and rigorously curated talent, and is described by the artists themselves as one of the best art shows in the country. This year we decided to pay a visit as a family. And although the younger two would crap out early from the mild heat and post-rainy day humidity, we did manage to hang around just long enough for me to discover my new favorite artist, Alla Tsank.

More on her later.

item.title: More Pasadena Eats
Abiri Sushi and Ramen
item.description: Spicy tonkatsu ramen is why God created pigs, and the Japanese. üçúüç∂

item.title: Antiques, Part 3
Your Excuse To Dress Up Like Harry and Hermione
item.description: Something that popped up in my Instagram feed. Win a trip for two to London? Maybe a good excuse for a little Harry/Hermione cosplay. Might have to borrow the kid‚Äôs graduation robe…

item.title: Golden Girls, Really?
item.description: First off, this. Nostalgia community, we need to have a deep and confronting conversation. It‚Äôs time to stop pretending you like The Golden Girls. Nobody but your grandma liked The Golden Girls, and that‚Äôs exactly as it should be. Your unnatural determination to make The Golden Girls a ‚Äúthing‚Äù amongst thirty-something males has led to this abomination, and it‚Äôs time we as a society put an end to this madness.

item.title: Leaving On A Jetplane
item.description: üõ´üåÉ Well, it‚Äôs been a busy few days. It‚Äôs a lot of work graduating a kid. Between that and home and my professional duties I‚Äôve been swamped. Such is the life of a dad. Since my last teaser post it‚Äôs only now that I feel like I can catch my breath a bit and recollect on some things I‚Äôd like to share with you. Hope you all are having a warm and magical evening.

item.title: Coming soon... Cottonwood Art Festival
item.description: Working on a blog about our trip to the Cottonwood Art Festival in Richardson, where I think I discovered my new favorite artist.

item.title: Taro Liquid Lunch
item.description: A mostly liquid lunch, but not too bad, considering. It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve had a Taro Boba. It may be my favorite flavor, and is something like blueberry crossed with macadamia nut.

item.title: Working Out
item.description: Good morning. üåû Guess I‚Äôm doing a bit of advertisement for the fish lady, but the coffee‚Äôs on point today.

item.title: Taco Naan Lunch
item.description: Happy Taco Tuesday, guys. üåÆ üíØ

item.title: Autobots
item.description: See that Transformers insignia on that Corolla? I had that idea. Back in 1986. And now some jerk is getting rich off my idea. Yep. Putting Transformers insignia on Corollas. All mine.

item.title: A Good Night For a Drink ü•É
item.description: It feels like a good night for a drink.

item.title: Great Tits
item.description: Found at the Cottonwood Art festival. Great painting. Would like to find more like it. Let me Google that‚Ä¶

item.title: Kassi Blogs, Too
item.description: My wife Kassi recently started her own blog of a more private nature, and she’s written a wonderful article about all of the many things going on in our lives last week, including our baptism, preparation for Pascha, and the appearance of the first clusters of firewheels in Dallas. Take a look.

item.title: Dream Log: A New House
item.description: I woke up from a vivid dream this morning. I’d just arrived home from a business trip to California, and Kassi was very excited to show me the changes that had been made to our neighborhood in my absence. Everyone had gotten a new house, it seems, and the neighborhood itself had been newly laid out, and its boundaries expanded. Our house had been moved to the backside of the neighborhood by the creek, and the wooded area around the creek had been developed, so that our house, instead of looking out onto a wooded ravine as it would currently, was now at a “T” intersection in the middle of the larger neighborhood.

item.title: Baptized
item.description: Today, on Holy Saturday, I, my wife, and my young son will be baptized into the Russian Orthodox Church.

item.title: An All New üë®üèª‚Äçüíª Tobybase.com
item.description: I’ve been working on a site overhaul for my pro blog, Tobybase.com. Go check it out and tell me what you think! Now just need some new content‚Ä¶

item.title: The Hidden Dangers of AI
item.description: What exactly are you trying to tell me, Facebook?

item.title: The Resurrection of Archie Bunker
item.description: You would think that in this “woke” era the comedies of Norman Lear would be better appreciated, but I don’t think his many efforts to reboot his old series are going anywhere. Not because of any politically touchy subject matter, but because he saw the humanity in all of his characters, including those like Archie Bunker who he used to illustrate everything he saw as wrong with modern American attitudes, but whom he based on his own beloved father.

item.title: The diagonal crosswalks of Pasadena
item.description: One of the little things I appreciate about Old Town Pasadena are the diagonal crosswalks. Very convenient, but they always feel like I‚Äôm stepping out into traffic. üò≥üö∂üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüöå

Today I had a lot of reminders that there are people out there who love and care for me a great deal. My wife, parents, and children. My brothers, cousins, and family. Friends old and new. I am thankful for all of them. I am thankful for the things I have, inside and out. I am thankful for the places God has brought me to in the past year. I met a man on the street named Emery Lambus who asked me for a couple of bucks to buy lunch.

item.title: Avocado Toast
item.description: It‚Äôs adorable the way these Californians go on about their avocado toast. I have heard ‚Äúavocado toast‚Äù dropped about five times in the last couple of days. Reminds me of the way Texans love… tacos? I think I‚Äôm gonna have to eat some avocado toast before I get out of here. I‚Äôll let you guys know. ü•ë

item.title: Pasadena in Bloom
item.description: The streets of Old Town Pasadena are lined this April in pink and purple blooms. A little natural spring beauty. Something of a birthday treat from God.

item.title: Roof Access
item.description: I get irrationally excited when I see ROOF ACCESS. But it‚Äôs never actually accessible.

item.title: Stroll Around Lake Carolyn
Helvetica Now
item.description: “Helvetica Now is the tummy-tuck, facelift and lip filler we‚Äôve been wanting, but were too afraid to ask for,‚Äù said Abbott Miller

item.title: Sweet Times with @Kassiblog
Spring buds
item.description: All winter keep still. Naked, silent. Dream until spring ends cold‚Äôs vigil.

item.title: Flip Wilson
item.description: Today I passed up the opportunity to buy a vintage talking Flip Wilson doll that would tell me not to touch him inappropriately. #70s #beforenintendo

item.title: 300 Million Butterflies Coming To Texas
item.description: Well, what do you know. It looks like the Monarchs have come back to life. I shall be ready. üì∏

item.title: Third Sunday of Great Lent
Cappuccino in the Morning
item.description: A cappuccino is a wonderful way to start the morning. Though this morning I can say I‚Äôve had better. There was a guy here who had one of those ironic mustaches. He could make good coffee. I wonder where he went. And if he still has that mustache. And if he left, maybe, to startup some better place that specializes in morning cappuccinos? And where that place might be, and if they have WiFi?

item.title: Old Woman, Lost in Thought
Shadows in the Forest
Flowers and Graffiti
Bee üêù
St. Patrick‚Äôs Favorite Drink
item.description: Celebrating St. Patrick‚Äôs Day with a couple of Vodka Stingers. Kassi approves. üçÄ

item.title: The Smell of Rotten Pumpkins
item.description: The smell of rotting pumpkin is worse than dead bodies. Ah, from what I‚Äôve heard… We had one survive till now, though, and I‚Äôm thinking about making a St. Patty‚Äôs day carving. What do you think?

item.title: Contrail Rainbow
Selfie from Cali
item.description: That‚Äôs a wrap for this trip. It‚Äôs been fun trying a new hotel and exploring a different part of the city. Perhaps next time I‚Äôll try to take in more of the cultural life. There‚Äôs always something going on in Pasadena. Now home again to Texas and the people I love. See you soon!

item.title: Pasadena Streets
A Half-Price Books?
A Set of Antique Glasses
item.description: I always check out the glassware in antique shops. The Greek theme doesn’t really suit me, but I thought the ornate styling was good for a pic.

item.title: Pasadena Street Musician
Horn Player
item.description: A street musician doing his thing in Old Town Pasadena.

item.title: First Mulch of the Season
item.description: I just smelled fresh mulch for the first time this year. Pungent, warm, green. I could feel the natural heat of it as they scooped it off the back of a flatbed as I walked by on the street.

item.title: Positive Feedback
item.description: I‚Äôve received some very nice compliments while I‚Äôve been here this week. It‚Äôs always great to get positive feedback for the work you put in. It makes a big difference in your day. üë®üèª‚Äçüíªü¶∏üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è I hope your day is going well, too!

item.title: Antiques, Part 2
Antiques
Pok√©mon Go In Pasadena
Old Methodist Church
item.description: The interesting things you run across when you decide to walk the mile and a half back to the hotel instead of Uber-ing. This is an old Methodist Church in the Playhouse District of Pasadena. Almost looks like an entrance to another world. A secret garden. A little foreboding perhaps. There was a lot about this area I‚Äôd like to explore. I‚Äôll be back again.

item.title: Let‚Äôs Play Poison
item.description: There’s someone buried under there. That’s the name. And see the date? Poison! Get off!

item.title: For the Lightly Bosomed Woman
item.description: I see what you did there, Flattery. And for the moderately bosomed woman? Out of luck, I suppose‚Ä¶ üëô

item.title: Tombstone Ideas
item.description: What I want my tombstone to look like, except with Firewheels and dandelions.

item.title: Morning Prayers
item.description: The years of my life have, like a spider, spun out their tale. Psalm 89

item.title: Back in L.A.
Forgiveness Sunday
item.description: Today in church I prostrated myself, whuch is to say I bowed deeply, with knees and forehead touching the floor, to my spiritual fathers and to every single other person present, and asked forgiveness for the things I have done that caused them offense. And they in turn asked me. The little kids. The old folks. My personal friends, and people to whom I’ve never spoken a word. We forgave each other, and reminded each other that God forgives.

item.title: Plano Trade Days
Rise and Shine
item.description: Rise and shine, people.

item.title: Happy Spring!
item.description: Happy springtime to all you players out there. The weather‚Äôs warming up here in Texas. We‚Äôre coming out of winter. I think we‚Äôre through the worst of it. Are you looking for signs of new growth? Look to the trees! They‚Äôre always the first to show.

item.title: Forestwood Antique Mall: Artifacts
Ash Wednesday, Great Lent
item.description:
Today is Ash Wednesday, the Catholic holy day that begins the penitential season of Lent. This year I will not be celebrating as a Catholic.

Last year on September 1st Kassi and I, after a long season of spiritual apathy and suffering, took our first steps into the Russian Orthodox Church. There were private reasons, of course. Personal reasons that are always at the core of any conversion; but also open reasons. We did not take the step lightly.

item.title: Tonight You Belong To Me
item.description: I’ve had this song stuck in my head for a couple of days, and maybe if I post it I can get rid of it. It’s from The Jerk, and features Bernadette Peters, my first screen crush when I was just a little kid. That bit at the end where she pulls out the coronet still cracks me up. Still, it’s a touching scene, don’t you think? A little reminder that life can be sweet sometimes.

item.title: Infexxion-34
item.description: Infexxion is an iPhone game based on the old arcade game Attax. My cousin Carl introduced me to it. There was a cabinet in the lobby of a (surely long-since demolished?) movie theater in what is now a rough part of Lafayette, Louisiana. I forget what we were seeing that night. He played ‚Äî I didn’t, as I recall. It had a weird, edgy kind of quality to it, like an Exidy game.

item.title: Lovebirds
What the Hell is This Poster For the Sonic the Hedgehog Movie?
item.description: The Sonic the Hedgehog movie comes out this year. Are you hyped, nostalgia boys?! Because if you look at this poster and get hyped, I’m calling the cops. Seriously, who designed this freakish movie poster and why is he/she not in jail/hell?

item.title: Out West Again
item.description: What should I say? What can I say? Perhaps a little about where I find myself these days. What I’m up to. Best keep it brief. I want to encourage myself to update these pages a little more frequently this year.

item.title: Greek Mythology
item.description: Yesterday the kid was watching an episode of the old Ghostbusters cartoon from the 80s, his new favorite on Netflix. The show featured the three Fates, and a journey to the Underworld, crossing the river Styx, etc. I said to him “Did you know this is Greek mythology? These were things the ancient Greeks believed.” He looked at me incredulously for a second and asked “They believed in the Ghostbusters?” ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

item.title: From Vermeule to Newman
item.description: Even if Francis is a liberal, it is far from clear to us that the proper response is liberalism. This, then, is the crux of the problem. Barring the Head of the Church returning, there will be other popes. Perhaps some will be, in the words of the great Louisiana philosopher and theologian I.J. Reilly, good authoritarian popes. Perhaps some will be liberals. However, the anti-liberal position works as well with a good authoritarian pope as it does with a liberal pope.

item.title: Revelation 17
item.description:
A meditation on a figure of the last days.

üìñ Revelation 17, KJV

And there came one of the seven angels which had the seven vials, and talked with me, saying unto me, Come hither; I will shew unto thee the judgment of the great whore that sitteth upon many waters: with whom the kings of the earth have committed fornication, and the inhabitants of the earth have been made drunk with the wine of her fornication.

item.title: Not the same
item.description: I find myself looking forward to November. Halloween is just not the same this year.

item.title: A Frank Zappa Halloween Costume
item.description: I think I just found my Halloween costume for this year. How did I ever miss this? It debuted just last year for the 40th anniversary celebration of Frank Zappa’s legendary Halloween concert series at The Palladium in New York. Zappa did Halloween concerts throughout the entirety of his career, but the one in 1977 is generally considered to be the apogee of that grand tradition. To commemorate that series of shows (which ran from October 28-31), the family released a massive box set that includes all six concerts on a USB stick, in 24-bit WAV audio for a flawless sound experience, PLUS a jaw-dropping adult size Frank Zappa costume in vintage 70s plastic style.

item.title: The Halloween & Hauntfest Convention
item.description: Normally scheduled in late August, the Halloween & Hauntfest show is appropriately billed as “a gateway event to the Halloween season.” To those of us who kick off our official celebrations with the start of Dinosaur Dracula’s Halloween Countdown on September 1, the timing hits that perfect sweet spot. The anticipation, that period of time I like to call “the run-up to the countdown”, starts to build throughout August, so that by the time this event rolls around Kassi and the kids and I are practically bursting with Halloween excitement.

item.title: When did people first start mowing lawns?
item.description: Today I mowed the back yard for the first time this spring. I am behind. The weather and other duties had kept me off task. The grass was high, and each square foot I tread into submission was like a territory reclaimed for civilization. I asked myself when people started doing this whole thing. Exactly how old is the time honored American activity of mowing the lawn? And why is this mundane chore, as therapeutic and contemplative as it is, not shown more love by those in the Big Nostalgia set, so connected as it is to real childhood and adolescent memory?

item.title: Maneki Neko Exhibit at the San Francisco Airport
The Toby Awards
item.description: And the Toby for Outstanding Building of the Year goes to‚Ä¶ (Cut to rival building management teams dressed up in tuxedos, sitting on the edge of their seats.) Makes me wonder what a Toby looks like. Today, too sick to care.

item.title: Greetings from Redwood City
The Year in Pictures ‚Äî¬†2017 Edition
item.description: Some of my favorite pictures from the past year. See the full set on Flickr.

item.title: A Halloween Run to Toys R Us
The Total Solar Eclipse of 2017!
Skull Eggs for Breakfast
Chisholm Trail in Watercolor
The Year in Pictures ‚Äî 2015 Edition
item.description: You have unlocked secret bonus content! Welcome to this retroactively inserted yearly retrospective. The date I am writing this is actually December 30, 2020. If you’ve found this page, that means you’ve stumbled upon some content that, while genuinely old, was not originally posted on this date. Greetings from the future! Or something. I suppose I could make some joke right now warning you to “turn back” from the dread year 2020, but that whole bit seems tired and depressing.

item.title: A Pumpkin for St. Michael
item.description: September 29th is the feast of St. Michael the Archangel, or Michaelmas as it is known in European countries. St. Michael cast the devil out of heaven, and is the commander of the armies of God. He is traditionally shown fighting a dragon, or with his foot on the back of the devil. He is the patron of soldiers and police officers, but also of the ill and suffering. He has appeared to people at various times curing diseases.

item.title: Diana Levin's Pocket Watch
Texas Frightmare Weekend
item.description: This year I attended Texas Frightmare Weekend for the first time. By now it seems like forever ago. But lucky you ‚Äî I saved all the pictures! So here they are without much verbal adornment, or it’d probably take me another month and a half to get this up.

item.title: Screening Phantasm With The Tall Man
item.description:
From a respectful write-up on Texas Frightmare Weekend by Dread Central:

Can we stop calling Texas Frightmare Weekend a ‚Äúregional con‚Äù now? The first reader I met this year was Aaron from Australia, who had flown all the way here to experience TFW as his FIRST con.

item.title: Noshing Tacos with Review the World
item.description: Once again we were proud to host buddy Brian Hammons of the food/candy/retro/life blog Review the World as he made his way down to Dallas for the big UFC 185 fight night. What a weekend! Among other things, I introduced Brian Hammons to some of the best tacos in the COUNTRY. Go see what resulted over on reviewtheworld.com.

item.title: The Year in Pictures
item.description: Being a fan of post-Christmas year end wrap-ups, I decided to create a Flickr set highlighting some of the events and activities that filled our lives this year. These are not my best photos or even my favorites, but just a (largish) collection of pictures that capture the essence of 2014 for me. A little bit of countryside, a little bit of life at home. One or two guest appearances.

item.title: Announcing the Very First Tobyblog Giveaway!
item.description: Would you like to win this original 8 x 10 photograph that hung in our house this past Halloween?

item.title: Review the World Comes to Dallas
item.description: Those of you paying close attention will remember that Tobyblog owes its existence to my good buddy Brian Hammons of the nostalgia blog reviewtheworld.com. His site is a surprisingly deep personal catalog that is as much a call to action and personal philosophical movement as anything.

item.title: The Iconography of Halloween: Skeletons
Retropalooza
item.description: Yesterday I took the kids to the amazing Retropalooza convention in Arlington, Texas, and boy did we have a blast! There were loads and loads of dealer tables with some very cool nostalgia items on display, classic and rare games galore, cosplayers, and even a few YouTube celebrities. Take a look at some of the fun things we discovered.

item.title: The Real Star of Phantasm
item.description: Here you go, folks, the real star of Phantasm ‚Äî that bad-ass muscle car! A real thing of beauty, and I’m not even that much of a car guy.

item.title: Spirit Halloween Store Opening Soon
item.description: Took a little stroll through the neighborhood this morning, and what should we find? Come September, tune in to Tobyblog for further details!

item.title: A Visit To The Toy Store
item.description: The great thing about being a dad to small kids is that you always have a built-in excuse to be in the toy aisle. And if you have your kids with you then nobody looks twice at you as you gawk at all the amazing stuff on the store shelves these days. We are living in a golden age for toys and board games. Sure, there were a lot of really cool toys that I miss from the seventies and eighties that I wish my kids had a chance to experience, but today’s market offers a certain quality and vast variety of toys and other amusements that the old days could never touch.

item.title: Don't Worry, Be Happy
item.description: And that would make him the first of our kids to eat a Happy Meal. Not sure if I like the new mascot. He tried to eat the baby’s noony.

item.title: First Halloween Merch of the Year
item.description: Technically spotted on July 1 at Michaels. Thanks to Swagger Mom for the tip-off about fall going up this week. That made me wonder, and my suspicions checked out.

item.title: Summer is Coming
item.description: In fact, it’s already here. My woodland trekking has been sidelined a bit due to having to nurse a sumac rash, but I’ll be back soon enough. Here’s hoping you guys get out and sweat a bit this summer. Enjoy the late evenings while you can! DST. What a gift from Mr. Nixon!

item.title: Wylie's Angel
item.description:
I like geocaching for lots of reasons. I like to be outside. I like discovering new places. I like walking and connecting with nature. But occasionally I learn something as well. Usually it’s just local historical trivia, or maybe a geography lesson. But sometimes the lesson is more personal, and as in this case, tragic.

The morning started out with a trip to the Trinity Trails in Wylie, Texas for some hiking and caching. We chose to start at the easternmost trailhead, which was also the closest to us.

There was a little marina at the trailhead.

item.title: A Day of Decisions
item.description: I’m celebrating a major personal milestone today, and I can’t think of a more fitting way to commemorate it on this site than by encouraging you all to watch one of my favorite episodes of The Ray Bradbury Theater from 1989, The Wonderful Death of Dudley Stone. This episode is indeed all about decisions, priorities, and focusing on what’s important in life. Part 1 Part 2 Part 3

item.title: The Beginning.
item.description: My name is Toby. In the spring of 2013 I discovered Brian Hammons' blog Review the World, and something inside clicked. Here was a guy ‚Äî just slightly my junior ‚Äî getting out and enjoying life with his friends, exploring his local environment, and generally on fire with all the possibilities that an ordinary life offers to those who know how to look for them. I had spent the bulk of 2012 doing all of those things with my two older kids while my wife was, for the most part (and regrettably), stuck at home working and/or gestating.
